title: Gary Lineker breaks down in tears as he says  I cant be silent
body_text:
Gary Lineker breaks down in tears as he says 'I can't be silent'
Gary Lineker has spoken out on the situation in Gaza and said he "can't be silent" - despite BBC rules
BBC's Match of the Day host and football icon, Gary Lineker, was visibly moved as he discussed the dire situation in Gaza, declaring it "the worst thing I've seen in my life" and emphasising, "I can't be silent about what's happening."
Despite BBC presenters being expected to adhere to strict impartiality rules, the renowned presenter did not shy away from expressing his views on the Israeli military actions following the October 7 Hamas terror attacks, which resulted in the loss of around 1,500 Israeli lives. Following these events, orders from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for bombings and ground operations have led to over 34,800 Palestinian casualties, with a significant number being women and children, according to figures from the Gaza Health Ministry.
In an emotional exchange with Zeteo, the media outlet founded by British-American journalist Mehdi Hasan, Lineker shared: "It's the worst thing I've seen in my life. I've got no skin in this game. I'm not Muslim, I'm not Jewish, I'm not Israeli, I'm not Palestinian.", reports Leicestershire Live.

Lineker concluded with a poignant reflection: "So I see it, I think, purely from the outside as from a neutral perspective. And I can't think of anything that I've seen worse in my lifetime, the constant images of children losing their lives day in day out."
In an outspoken comment, he disclosed: "Obviously, we all know October 7 happened and but the minute you raise your voice against what they're now doing you get accused of being a supporter of Hamas and this kind of stuff. There is a lot of heavy lobbying on people to be quiet so I understand why most people refrain, but I'm getting on a bit now, I'm fairly secure and I can't be silent about what's happening there.
"I think it's so so utterly awful and it already looks like it's happening, going into Rafa, where they've sent everybody down there. It's not antisemitic to say that what Israel is doing is wrong.
"I just can't see how everybody doesn't see that now, whatever the cause, whatever started it, we all know that, the history of this area, of the world goes way before October 7. But it's, it's truly dreadful, what's happening and I cry on a regular basis when I see certain images on social media."
Lineker experienced an interim removal from Match of the Day on March 10, 2023 after his stinging criticism of what he characterised as "an immeasurably cruel policy directed at the most vulnerable people in language that is not dissimilar to that used by Germany in the 30s". Famous commentators including Alan Shearer, Ian Wright and Jermaine Jenas pulled out from their scheduled appearances as a sign of unity, leading to his rapid reinstatement.
The BBC's report, released in September, featured reference to flagship programmes such as Match of the Day, The Apprentice, Dragon's Den and The One Show. The document stated that presenters are banned from supporting or criticising any political party during a broadcast, with this rule also applying for two weeks before and after the series.
Despite endorsing freedom of speech, the guidelines limit conversation about individual UK politicians' character, declarations on contentious issues during an election period, and adopting a formal role with a lobbying group. In response to these restrictions, Lineker voiced his approval, terming them as "eminently sensible".
